learning_outcomes.description: Identify and analyse the impacts tourism, hospitality and events have on sustainability.
Apply systems thinking to analyse the sustainability of a tourism, hospitality, event system.
Develop and use critical thinking and academic writing skills to complete all assessment tasks.
Collaboratively work in teams to prepare a report on a tourism, hospitality, event system.

assessments.task_description:
Note: Assessment 1 (Desk Audit) and Assessment 2 (Impact Analysis) are related. The planning and feedback from Assessment 1 will be used by you to develop Assessment 2

Assessment 1 - Desk Audit

  • Individual task.
  • 800-1000 words (excluding Title Page, AI/MT Statement, Table of Contents, Reference List)

As an expert in sustainability, you have been engaged by the management team of a tourism/ hospitality/ event (T/H/E) activity to evaluate the sustainability of the activity. Your first task is to complete a desk audit of your activity to make an initial assessment of its sustainability status.

Your task:

  1. Identify a T/H/E activity (hereafter activity) that you will evaluate.
  2. This can be an accommodation establishment; an event/ event venue; or a tourist attraction.
  3. Each activity can only be chosen by one student.
  4. Do NOT choose South Bank (Brisbane), a casino, or Lady Elliot Island Eco Resort.
  5. By Week 3 you MUST get your activity approved by the teaching team.
  6. Prepare a desk audit of your activity. Using secondary information (e.g. internet sites, publicly available reports) prepare a document that:
  • Describes your activity.
  • Justifies what the term ‘sustainability’ means to you.
  • Provides your initial evaluation of the sustainability status of your activity.

IMPORTANT: You can NOT approach employees, management or visitors to your activity. This is a breach of UQ policy. This assessment is based on information you find from your desk research (publicly available information). You will not be conducting surveys, interviewing people or visiting your activity.

See the Assessment Helper for a detailed explanation of the requirements of this assessment task.

Use of AI/MT Technologies

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that can support this type of activity. Therefore, you are allowed to appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. However, in every instance where AI or MT is used, you must clearly reference its use.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

Format: 

  • Referencing: APA7
  • Font size: 11 point
  • Font type: Calibri; Times New Roman; Arial
  • Line spacing: 1.5 spacing

See the Marking Rubric for full details of the marking criteria.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Your completed Desk Audit of your T/H/E Activity must be submitted to Turnitin, which is accessed from Blackboard through the Assessment link.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
Note: Assessment 1 (Desk Audit) and Assessment 2 (Impact Analysis) are related. The planning and feedback from Assessment 1 will be used by you to develop Assessment 2

Assessment 2 - Impact Analysis

  • Individual task
  • 2000 words (excluding Title Page; AI/MT Statement; Table of Contents; Reference List; Appendices)

Building on your Desk Audit (Assessment 1) you are required to visit your T/H/E activity (hereafter activity) to identify and assess impacts. This assessment requires you to determine if the findings of your desk audit are consistent with your observations at the activity. Then prepare a more complete evaluation of the status of sustainability, including recommendations, for the manager of your activity. 

Your task:

1.   Visit your activity from your Desk Audit (Assessment 1) to identify impacts.

2.   Gather evidence of the impacts. This will primarily be photos that you take. At least one photo must include you (a selfie).

3.   Analyse the information you have gathered in conjunction with the information from your Desk Audit.

4.   Prepare an Impact Analysis for the manager of your activity.

Your Impact Analysis must include the following sections:

  • Title Page
  • AI/MT Statement
  • Table of Contents
  • Introduction
  • Sustainability Status
  • Recommendations
  • Reference List
  • Appendices

IMPORTANT: You can NOT approach employees, management or visitors to your activity. This is a breach of UQ policy. This assessment is based on your observations and information you find from your desk research (publicly available information). You will not be conducting surveys or interviewing people.

See the Assessment Helper for a detailed explanation of the requirements of this assessment task.

Use of AI/MT Technologies

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that can support this type of activity. Therefore, you are allowed to appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. However, in every instance where AI or MT is used, you must clearly reference its use.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

Formatting:

  • Referencing: APA7
  • Font size: 11 point
  • Font type: Calibri; Times New Roman; Arial
  • Line spacing: 1.5 spacing

See the Marking Rubric for full details of the marking criteria.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Your completed Impact Analysis must be submitted to Turnitin, which is accessed from Blackboard through the Assessment link.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.category: Paper/ Report/ Annotation, Participation/ Student contribution
assessments.task_description:
Assessment 3: Systems Report

  • Team task (3-4 students per team)
  • 3500-4000 words (excluding Title Page; AI/MT Statement; Executive Summary; Table of Contents; Reference List; Appendices – if used).

Due to your expertise in tourism, hospitality and event (THE) management, your team has been hired as consultants to prepare a System Report for the manager of a T/H/E business.

Your Task:

The T/H/E business you will be preparing and writing the report for is the tourism OR hospitality OR event (T/H/E) business you will be working on in class with your team.

Your team members will be the group of randomly selected students the teaching team assigned you to work with in class.

AS A TEAM:

  • Prepare a report for the manager of your T/H/E business. Your report will be based on a tourism system developed for one (1) potential, or existing, target market for your T/H/E business.
  • Include the following in your report:
  • Title page
  • AI/MT Statement
  • Executive summary
  • Table of contents
  • Introduction
  • System
  • In this section, include:
  • Diagram of your system
  • Explanation of your system
  • Conclusion
  • Recommendations
  • Reference list
  • Appendices (if needed)

IMPORTANT: You can NOT approach employees, management or visitors to your business. This is a breach of UQ policy. This assessment is based on your analysis of publicly available information. You will not be conducting surveys or interviewing people.

See the Assessment Helper for a detailed explanation of the requirements of this assessment task.

Use of AI/MT Technologies

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that can support this type of activity. Therefore, you are allowed to appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. However, in every instance where AI or MT is used, you must clearly reference its use.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, you will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of your written submission independent of AI and MT tools.

Formatting:

  • Referencing: APA7
  • Font size: 11 point
  • Font type: Calibri; Times New Roman; Arial
  • Line spacing: 1.5 spacing

Marking Criteria:

To ensure all team members are contributing equally to the report, some compulsory check points have been put in place for this assessment task. These check points are designed to alert you/ your teaching team to any issues you and/or your team are experiencing, and allow you time to rectify these issues prior to submission.

1.   Systems Report (Team)

See the Marking Rubric for full details of the marking criteria.

2.   Oral Check-in (individual)

  • Provide verbal responses to randomly selected questions related to your team Systems Report
  • 5 minutes per student
  • 2 opportunities to complete your Oral Check-in:

o  An allocated time during Week 13

o  An allocated time the day after your Systems Report is due (that is, during exam block)

  • Pass/fail task. Fail results in a mark of 0/40 for the individual. Fail includes no attempt made to complete an Oral Check-in.

See the Assessment Helper for full details of Oral Check-in

3.   Buddycheck (individual)

  • Peer assessment tool completed by 5pm on the day your Systems Report is submitted.
  • Your Buddycheck score will determine how many marks you are awarded for the Systems Report
  • In Week 11 you will do an individual formative (not for marks) Buddycheck to identify any team issues.

See the Assessment Helper for full details of the use of Buddycheck.
assessments.submission_guidelines: One member of your team must submit the completed Systems Report to Turnitin, which is accessed from Blackboard through the Assessment link.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

learning_activities.topic:
Introduction to tourism, hospitality and events (THE)

This week we get to know each other and ensure we have a shared understanding of the key terms used in this course - tourism, hospitality, events. We also explore the course profile so you know where to look for key information throughout the semester.
learning_activities.topic_description: Introduction to tourism, hospitality and events (THE) This week we get to know each other and ensure we have a shared understanding of the key terms used in this course - tourism, hospitality, events. We also explore the course profile so you know where to look for key information throughout the semester.

learning_activities.topic:
Sustainability - economic impacts

It is important that the tourism, hospitality and events (THE) industries that we discussed last week are sustainable. But what does 'sustainable' mean? We explore sustainability from a triple bottom line approach and introduce the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and the Global Code of Ethics for Tourism. This sets the scene for a more indepth discussion about the economic impacts of THE, with a focus on the tourism multiplier. We introduce the first two assessment tasks and highlight how to use AI appropriately in this course.
learning_activities.topic_description: Sustainability - economic impacts It is important that the tourism, hospitality and events (THE) industries that we discussed last week are sustainable. But what does 'sustainable' mean? We explore sustainability from a triple bottom line approach and introduce the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and the Global Code of Ethics for Tourism. This sets the scene for a more indepth discussion about the economic impacts of THE, with a focus on the tourism multiplier. We introduce the first two assessment tasks and highlight how to use AI appropriately in this course.

learning_activities.topic:
Advanced database searching and Referencing

An important part of developing your critical analysis skills is being able to source scholarly articles. This week we start our class in the library with an interactive session on advanced database searching. Then we return to the class room where we unpack APA7 referencing format and consider how to incorporate scholarly material into our academic writing.
learning_activities.topic_description: Advanced database searching and Referencing An important part of developing your critical analysis skills is being able to source scholarly articles. This week we  start our class in the library with an interactive session on advanced database searching. Then we return to the class room where we unpack APA7 referencing format and consider how to incorporate scholarly material into our academic writing.

learning_activities.topic:
Sustainability: socio-cultural impacts

This week we start with a reminder from Student Services about the support services that are available to you - for free. Then we continue our exploration of sustainability by focusing on the social and cultural impacts of tourism. We explore the impacts THE have on host communities and the importance of working with host communities to ensure the tourism experience is beneficial for everyone - both socially/ culturally and economically.
learning_activities.topic_description: Sustainability: socio-cultural impacts This week we start with a reminder from Student Services about the support services that are available to you - for free. Then we continue our exploration of sustainability by focusing on the social and cultural impacts of tourism. We explore the impacts THE have on host communities and the importance of working with host communities to ensure the tourism experience is beneficial for everyone - both socially/ culturally and economically.

learning_activities.topic:
Sustainability: environmental impacts

This week we explore the environmental impacts of THE. These are the impacts we often hear about in the media but what does 'environment' mean? We explore impacts on the natural and built environments and we discuss how much change is too much change. Incorporating the learnings from Weeks 2 and 4, we start to get a sense of the connections between the different types of impacts.
learning_activities.topic_description: Sustainability: environmental impacts This week we explore the environmental impacts of THE. These are the impacts we often hear about in the media but what does 'environment' mean? We explore impacts on the natural and built environments and we discuss how much change is too much change. Incorporating the learnings from Weeks 2 and 4, we start to get a sense of the connections between the different types of impacts.

learning_activities.topic:
Excursion - South Bank

This week we meet at South Bank, Brisbane, where you undertake an audit of the impacts of THE. This excursion gives you insights into how to apply classroom learning to the real world - which you will find particularly useful for Assessment 2 (Impact Analysis). There is also an online module for you to complete this week. This module steps you through how to analyse the impacts you identified at South Bank. This skill will be required to complete Assessment 2.
learning_activities.topic_description: Excursion - South Bank This week we meet at South Bank, Brisbane, where you undertake an audit of the impacts of THE. This excursion gives you insights into how to apply classroom learning to the real world - which you will find particularly useful for Assessment 2 ( Impact Analysis ). There is also an online module for you to complete this week. This module steps you through how to analyse the impacts you identified at South Bank. This skill will be required to complete Assessment 2.
In-Semester Break No classes this week.

learning_activities.topic:
Sustainability - managing impacts

So far this semester we have focused on identifying impacts. This week we consider strategies to manage these impacts so we can minimise the negative impacts and maximise the positive impacts. We start with a case study of Lady Elliot Island Eco Resort, which has won many awards for its sustainable practices. Then we expand this learning to scenarios that involve a variety of stakeholders.
learning_activities.topic_description: Sustainability - managing impacts So far this semester we have focused on identifying impacts. This week we consider strategies to manage these impacts so we can minimise the negative impacts and maximise the positive impacts. We start with a case study of Lady Elliot Island Eco Resort, which has won many awards for its sustainable practices. Then we expand this learning to scenarios that involve a variety of stakeholders.

learning_activities.topic:
Systems theory and THE

We have explored the impact of THE at sites. Now we expand our thinking to consider THE from a systems perspective. What is needed to make THE function? Importantly we have the insights to consider the use of sustainable principles to underpin our discussion of tourism systems.
learning_activities.topic_description: Systems theory and THE We have explored the impact of THE at sites. Now we expand our thinking to consider THE from a systems perspective. What is needed to make THE function? Importantly we have the insights to consider the use of sustainable principles to underpin our discussion of tourism systems.

learning_activities.topic:
Tourism System - tourist and generating region

Tourists are the lifeblood of a tourism system - without them the tourism system has no purpose. But tourists are only one element of a tourism system. The importance of the generating region (the tourist's hometown/ country) is often overlooked. This week we explore the role of these elements of the tourism system. We also start working on Assessment 3 (Systems Report). We explain the expectations of the assessment task and we explore strategies for working effectively in teams.
learning_activities.topic_description: Tourism System - tourist and generating region Tourists are the lifeblood of a tourism system - without them the tourism system has no purpose. But tourists are only one element of a tourism system. The importance of the generating region (the tourist's hometown/ country) is often overlooked. This week we explore the role of these elements of the tourism system. We also start working on Assessment 3 ( Systems Report ). We explain the expectations of the assessment task and we explore strategies for working effectively in teams.

learning_activities.topic:
Tourism System - transit region

This week we start with a visit from the Work Integrated Learning (WIL) team to explain how to access work placements and internships during your program of study. Then we continue our exploration of the tourism system by focusing on the transit region. Despite the name, this is more than different types of transport. During the seminar you work with your team to develop your system for Assessment 3 (Systems Report). We will also start unpacking the structure of your Systems Report - is an introduction and conclusion the same content in different words?
learning_activities.topic_description: Tourism System - transit region This week we start with a visit from the Work Integrated Learning (WIL) team to explain how to access work placements and internships during your program of study. Then we continue our exploration of the tourism system by focusing on the transit region. Despite the name, this is more than different types of transport. During the seminar you work with your team to develop your system for Assessment 3 ( Systems Report ). We will also start unpacking the structure of your Systems Report - is an introduction and conclusion the same content in different words?

learning_activities.topic:
Tourism System - destination region (tourist perspective)

The part of the tourism system that gets a lot of attention is the destination - we spend two weeks exploring this region. This week we explore the destination region from the tourist perspective. What do tourists expect of the destinations they visit? Are they aware of their impacts? Do they care? You continue working with your team to apply this learning to Assessment 3 (Systems Report). This week we revisit our learnings from Assessment 2 (Impact Analysis) about writing recommendations. You will also do a formative Buddy Check.
learning_activities.topic_description: Tourism System - destination region (tourist perspective) The part of the tourism system that gets a lot of attention is the destination - we spend two weeks exploring this region. This week we explore the destination region from the tourist perspective. What do tourists expect of the destinations they visit? Are they aware of their impacts? Do they care? You continue working with your team to apply this learning to Assessment 3 ( Systems Report ). This week we revisit our learnings from Assessment 2 ( Impact Analysis) about writing recommendations. You will also do a formative Buddy Check.

learning_activities.topic:
Tourism System - destination region (management perspective)

Continuing our discussion of the destination region, this week we focus on the management perspective. We consider how models like the Tourism Area Life Cycle (TALC) can be used as a management tool. You will work in your team to apply these discussions to Assessment 3 (Systems Report). This week we focus on an often overlooked part of reports - the executive summary.
learning_activities.topic_description: Tourism System - destination region (management perspective) Continuing our discussion of the destination region, this week we focus on the management perspective. We consider how models like the Tourism Area Life Cycle (TALC) can be used as a management tool. You will work in your team to apply these discussions to Assessment 3 ( Systems Report ). This week we focus on an often overlooked part of reports - the executive summary.

learning_activities.topic:
Tourism System - external influences

In our final week we consider external influences that could impact our system. This includes a discussion about the role of government in the tourism system - and the different ways of governing. You will work in your team to relate this information into Assessment 3 (Systems Report). We finish with a short review of the semester's learnings.

Outside of class time you have the option of completing your compulsory Oral Check-in for Assessment 3 (Systems Report).
learning_activities.topic_description: Tourism System - external influences In our final week we consider external influences that could impact our system. This includes a discussion about the role of government in the tourism system - and the different ways of governing. You will work in your team to relate this information into Assessment 3 ( Systems Report ). We finish with a short review of the semester's learnings. Outside of class time you have the option of completing your compulsory Oral Check-in for Assessment 3 ( Systems Report ).
